snippet: Money, not ideology, drove many men to join the Confederate Army in 1862.
abstract: Money, not ideology, drove many men to join the Confederate Army in 1862.
lead_paragraph: James H. Lee enlisted in the new 43rd Alabama Infantry in the spring of 1862. A man either poor enough or transient enough to have eluded the census taker two years earlier, Lee openly admitted that it was money, in the form of regular pay and a $50 bounty (akin to a signing bonus), that finally convinced him to rally to the colors. Writing from camp near Mobile, Ala., a few weeks later, he already regretted his decision. “We have not drawed one red cent,” he wrote his wife, “and from what I hear among the boys they havent more than one third of them ever drawed half of there bounty yet.”
